smell_analysis.justification: Every page labelled as a diagram contains visible elements (packages, use cases, classes, tables, states, or actions), for example the overview of registers on page 1, the use case diagram on page 2, and the DDL table layout on page 13; no page presents an empty diagram frame.

In the use case diagram 'Parklakohtade funktsionaalne allsüsteem' (page 2), all named use cases appear within the system boundary surrounded by several actors, and there is no explicit indication of any use case being unconnected to all actors; the PDF does not clearly show an isolated use case without associations, so no violation can be confirmed.

The use case diagram (page 2) shows distinct use case names such as 'Registreeri parklakoht', 'Aktiveeri parklakoht', 'Lõpeta parklakoht', 'Muuda parklakoht', and several 'Vaata ...' variants, but none are duplicate descriptions of the same activity for the same actor; each describes a different operation or view and there are no clearly synonymous pairs like 'Add Car' vs 'Register Car'.

In the package diagram 'Parklakoha FASiga seotud pädevusalad ja registrid' (page 1), each package lists unique classifier names within that package (for example, the 'Klassifikaatorite register' lists 'Klassifikaator', 'Riik', 'Parklakoha_seisundi_liik', etc.), and no package contains two separate model elements with exactly the same primary name; repeated classifier-type labels are display metadata rather than separate elements.

Across the database/DDL diagrams (pages 13-18), repeated business values such as status codes or category codes are consistently modelled as foreign keys pointing to dedicated classification tables (e.g., 'kliendi_seisundi_liik_kood', 'parklakoha_seisundi_liik_kood', 'parkla_seisundi_liik_kood'), and there is no clear case where the same data value is stored redundantly in different tables without a foreign key relationship; generic shared column names like 'reg_aeg' or 'viimase_muutm_aeg' represent different timestamps and are not denormalized copies of the same entity.

All use case names on the use case diagram (page 2) follow a consistent verb-first style, for example 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Registreeri parklakoht', 'Aktiveeri parklakoht', 'Lõpeta parklakoht', 'Muuda parklakoht', 'Unusta parklakoht', and 'Vaata ...' variants; there is no mixture of verb-named and purely noun-named use cases.

In the state diagram 'Parklakoha seisundidiagramm' (page 10), each state (Ootel, Aktiivne, Mitteaktiivne, Lõpetatud, Unustatud) has at least one incoming transition from either the initial state or another state; for example, Ootel is reached from the initial node, Aktiivne is reached from Ootel, Mitteaktiivne from Aktiivne, Lõpetatud from Aktiivne or Mitteaktiivne, and Unustatud from Ootel, so no state is unreachable.

Both activity diagrams ('Parklakoha lõpetamise tegevusdiagramm' on page 3 and 'Aktiveeri parklakoht tegevusdiagramm' on page 4) show each action node on at least one path starting from the initial node; actions such as viewing candidate parking places, searching, selecting, and completing or activating a parking place are all connected through decisions and flows, and there are no clearly isolated action boxes without incoming control flow.

In the conceptual class diagrams (pages 5-12), associations display multiplicity indicators like '1', '0..*', and '0..1' at their ends, while in the database diagrams (pages 13-18) relationships are represented using standard crow’s-foot or foreign-key notation (lines linked to PK/FK annotations); there is no visible UML-style association line entirely lacking multiplicity or implied crow’s-foot semantics at both ends.

Several diagrams exceed the 10 central-element threshold: the use case diagram on page 2 contains 11 distinct use cases; the 'Klassifikaatorite register' class diagram on page 7 contains at least 11 classifier classes (Klassifikaator, Riik, Parklakoha_seisundi_liik, Töötaja_seisundi_liik, Isiku_seisundi_liik, Töötaja_roll, Parklakoha_kategooria, Parklakoha_kategooria_tüüp, Kliendi_seisundi_liik, Parkla_seisundi_liik, Klassifikaatori tüüp); and the DDL diagram on page 13 shows around 17 tables, so this smell is present.

On the 'Klassifikaatorite register' class diagram (page 7), the central classifier type entity (labelled 'Klassifikaatori tüüp') is connected by separate lines to multiple classifier subclasses or related classes such as 'Riik', 'Parklakoha_seisundi_liik', 'Töötaja_seisundi_liik', 'Isiku_seisundi_liik', 'Töötaja_roll', 'Parklakoha_kategooria', 'Parklakoha_kategooria_tüüp', 'Kliendi_seisundi_liik', and 'Parkla_seisundi_liik'; this yields more than six distinct relationship lines attached to a single class on that diagram, exceeding the S1.2 threshold.

Although some diagrams (especially the DDL layout on page 13) contain long connectors, they appear proportionate to the overall diagram size, and there is no clear case where the distance between a pair of related elements is obviously more than twice the average inter-element distance for that diagram; without explicit extreme outliers, this smell cannot be confidently identified.

While all use case names start with active verbs, the 'Aktiveeri parklakoht' activity diagram (page 4) contains action names that do not start with an active verb, for example 'Parklahaldur/tehnik soovib parklakoha aktiveerida' begins with an actor noun phrase, and 'Parklakoht aktiveeritud' and 'Aktiveerimine ebaõnnestub' start with nouns rather than verbs; these are action nodes in the activity flow whose names violate the verb-first requirement.

Across use cases, classes, tables, and attributes shown in the diagrams (pages 2-18), names are composed of multi-character identifiers such as 'Parklakoht', 'Tootaja', 'parklakoht_kood', and 'on_nous_tylitamisega'; no class, table, attribute, or use case name consisting of three or fewer characters (like 'id' or 'car') is visible.

All visible class and table names start with uppercase letters (e.g., 'Isik', 'Töötaja', 'Parklakoht', 'Kasutajakonto', 'Klient', 'Parkla'), and names that include plurals are primarily register names such as 'Isikute register' or 'Klientide register', which are domain register tables explicitly excluded from this rule; no singular domain entity class starts with a lowercase initial or is plural.

In the conceptual 'Parklate register' class diagram (page 12), the 'Parkla' class declares an attribute named 'Aadress' with an initial uppercase 'A', which is an attribute/column name starting with an uppercase letter and therefore violates the lowercase-first convention; other attributes like 'korgus', 'reg_aeg', and 'kommentaar' are lowercase.

Tables representing singular domain entities (e.g., 'Isikute register::Isik', 'Klientide register::Klient', 'Parklate register::Parkla', 'Parklakohtade register::Parklakoht') use singular entity names, while plural forms occur only in register labels such as 'Isikute register' or 'Parklakohtade register', which are explicitly excluded as domain register tables; no individual entity table is named in the plural.

Class, table, and attribute names in the diagrams do not use type-indicative prefixes like 'tbl_', 'uc_', or 'strName'; the only prefixes present on the DDL diagrams (e.g., 'PK_Isik', 'FK_Klient_Isik', 'pfK klient_id', 'IXFK_Tootaja_Tootaja') relate to primary keys, foreign keys, and allowed FK index naming conventions, which are explicitly exempted from this rule.
